title: 106_s1560
content:
The "Shivwits Plateau National Conservation Area Establishment Act" establishes the Shivwits Plateau National Conservation Area to conserve landscapes, wildlife, vegetation, and cultural values for present and future generations. The Act defines the conservation area and the role of the Secretary of the Interior in its management. Establishment of Shivwits Plateau National Conservation Area in Arizona. The Shivwits Plateau National Conservation Area in Arizona covers approximately 381,800 acres of land in Mohave County. The Secretary will provide a map and legal description of the area to Congress for public inspection. The description of the area in the Shivwits Plateau National Conservation Area in Arizona will be available for public inspection at the Office of the Director of the Bureau of Land Management and the appropriate office in Arizona. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT OF CONSERVATION AREA. The Secretary manages the conservation area to conserve values specified in applicable laws. Hunting, fishing, and grazing are permitted in accordance with Arizona state laws. Forest restoration efforts are also carried out. The Secretary manages the conservation area to conserve values specified in applicable laws, including hunting, fishing, and grazing. Forest restoration projects are conducted on Ponderosa Pine and Pinion-Juniper forests with the goal of restoring the land to presettlement condition. An advisory committee, the "Shivwits Plateau National Conservation Area Advisory Committee," is established to advise the Secretary on the management plan. The advisory committee for the conservation area includes members from various backgrounds such as the Bureau of Land Management, Kaibab Band of Paiute Indians, ecological restoration, Arizona State Land Commissioner, Arizona State Game and Fish Commissioner, and an official from the State of Utah. The Planning Task Force for the conservation area includes representatives from environmental organizations, local elected officials from Arizona and Utah. Members serve 3-year terms, with initial appointments staggered between 1 and 2 years. Members of the advisory committee are appointed for a 2-year term and may be reappointed upon expiration. SEC. 6. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Secretary will manage the conservation area under existing resource management plans and future revisions must comply with the goals of this Act. SEC. 7. ACQUISITION OF LAND. The Secretary may acquire land within the conservation area through donation, purchase with funds, or exchange with willing parties. Within a 2-year period, efforts will be made to acquire State trust lands and mining claims through exchange. If an exchange is not completed, the property owner may declare their State trust lands. The owner of State trust lands, subsurface rights, or valid mining claims within the conservation area can declare that their property has been taken by inverse condemnation and seek compensation from the United States in district court. The United States shall pay fair market value for any property acquired, assessed as if the conservation area did not exist. SEC. 8. MINERAL ASSESSMENT PROGRAM AND RELATIONSHIP TO MINING LAWS. The Secretary will assess oil, gas, coal, uranium, and other mineral potential on Federal land in the conservation area. The mineral assessment program will be reviewed by the Arizona State Department of Mines and Mineral Resources before completion. Public land in the conservation area is withdrawn from mineral location, entry, and patent under the General Mining Law of 1872. The Secretary will allow the removal of minerals through leasing. The Secretary will permit the removal of nonleasable and leasable minerals from land within the national conservation area in accordance with specific Acts. Receipts from permits and leases issued on land in the conservation area will be managed as per relevant Acts. Receipts from the disposition of nonleasable minerals within the conservation area shall be managed in the same way as proceeds from the sale of public land under the Mineral Leasing Act for Acquired Lands. SEC. 9. EFFECT ON WATER RIGHTS.

This Act does not establish new water rights for the United States or authorize water appropriation, except as per Arizona state law.

SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS.

Funds necessary for implementing this Act can be appropriated.
